questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a small, flat, reddish-brown lesion on the palm of their hand. The lesion is non-palpable and measures approximately 5 mm in diameter. What is the most likely description of this lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Macule Explanation: A macule is a flat, non-raised lesion less than 1 cm in diameter characterized by a change in skin colour or pigmentation. Skin Lesions <1 cm Skin Lesions >1 cm Macule: Flat, non-raised lesion (Option C) Patch: Flat, non-raised lesion Papule: Raised, circumscribed, solid lesion (Option A ruled out) < 1cm Plaque: Elevated circumscribed lesion (Option B ruled out) > 1cm Vesicle: Circumscribed elevation less than < 1cm in diameter that contains fluid (clear, serous or haemorrhagic) and is often grouped Bullae: Bullae are more than > 1cm in diameter (Option D ruled out). Petechiae: Punctate haemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter. Ecchymoses: A macular area of haemorrhage more than 1cm (bruise) in diameter. Purpura: Haemorrhagic spots more than 3mm but less than 1cm caused by bleeding underneath the skin

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a complaint of red scaly lesion on his lower back. On examination, a well-demarcated, erythematous lesion measuring 4 cm in diameter with silvery scales on the surface is seen. What is the most likely diagnostic skin lesion present?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Plaque Explanation: The lesion is suggestive of plaque in psoriasis. Plaques are elevated circumscribed lesions > 1cm, Plaque in psoriasis is characterized by silvery scales on a thickened, erythematous base. Depending on the underlying cause, these lesions can be pink, red, brown, or skin-colored. Some common causes of plaques include: Psoriasis Eczema (specifically nummular eczema) Lichen planus Seborrheic dermatitis Pustule (Option A): A pustule is a type of skin lesion characterized by a small, circumscribed elevation of the skin that contains pus. Pustules are usually < 1cm in size Nodule (Option C): Nodules are a type of skin lesion characterized by solid, palpable, elevated masses that extend into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue. They are >1 cm in size and range in depth from 1 to 10 mm. Wheal (Option D): Wheals are a type of skin lesion characterized by transient, edematous (swollen), elevated areas on the skin. These areas are typically pink or red and have well-defined borders.

questions.question: Which of the following skin lesions is a localized collection of pus within the epidermis or dermis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pustule Explanation: A pustule is a small, circumscribed elevation of the skin containing pus. They typically appear as small, white or yellowish bumps on the skin's surface. Pustules may have a visible central point where the pus is located. Wheal (Option A): Wheal is a transient type of skin lesion characterized by edematous, swollen and elevated dermis and hypodermis. Nodules (Option C): Nodules are solid, palpable, elevated masses that extend into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue. They are larger and deeper than papules, which are similar in appearance but smaller. They are >1 cm in size and range in depth from 1 to 10 mm. Bullae (Option D): Bullae are blisters more than 1 cm on the skin that are filled with clear fluid

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary skin lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Purpura Explanation: Purpura is a primary skin lesion. It is a condition with red, discoloured spots on the skin that do not blanch on pressure. The spots are caused by bleeding underneath the skin. Purpura measure between 4 and 10 mm in diameter. When purpura spots are less than 4 mm in diameter, they are called Petechiae. Purpura spots larger than 1 cm are called Ecchymoses . All the below lesions are secondary skin lesions. Atrophy (Option A): Atrophy refers to the loss of tissue from either or all the layers of skin (Epidermis, Dermis, Subcutaneous tissue). If the process is superficial, there may be fine wrinkling and translucency. Induration (Option B): Induration refers to the dermal thickening that clinically appears firmer than normal on palpation. Crust (Option C): The crust consists of dried-up discharge from the lesions.

questions.question: Identify the skin lesion and the disease associated with the image below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Scales - Seborrheic dermatitis Explanation: Scales are visible exfoliation of the skin containing flakes of stratum corneum. Seborrheic dermatitis: Seborrheic dermatitis is characterized by yellow, greasy scales covering the scalp , extending to the hairline and behind the ears. Seborrheic dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition primarily affecting areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, and trunk. It is characterized by erythematous plaques with adherent, greasy scales, often associated with itching and mild redness. Fissures (Option A) are linear breaks or cracks in the skin that are not typically associated with seborrheic dermatitis. Atrophy (Option B) describes the thinning of the skin, resulting in a decrease in the thickness of the epidermis and dermis. Pityriasis rosea is not typically associated with atrophy. Target lesions (Option C) are less than 3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of oedema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well I defined edge. Pityriasis versicolor presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules with fine scaling, but it is not typically associated with target lesions.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of severe itching and thickened skin on his lower legs. Upon examination, well-demarcated areas of thickened, leathery skin with exaggerated skin markings are seen. He mentions that he has a history of atopic dermatitis and has been using topical corticosteroids intermittently for the past few years to manage flare-ups. Which of the following lesions is present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lichenification Explanation: Lichenification is characterised by the thickening of the Epidermis and dermis due to prolonged scratching. It is a secondary skin lesion associated with thick skin, hyperpigmentation and exaggerated skin markings. It is associated with the following characteristic features in HPE Acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis) Hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum) Elongation of rete ridges Chronic inflammatory infiltrate in the dermis. Erosion (Option A) is a loss of the epidermis, which heals without scarring. Ulcer (Option B) is a loss of the dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues. Poikiloderma (Option A) is an association of Cutaneous pigmentation (Hypo or Hyper pigmentation) Atrophy Telangiectasia (Visible dilatation of small blood vessels, particularly the capillaries, in the dermal layer of the skin).

questions.question: Which among the following is the pathway of epidermal cell migration during embryonic development and the most common disease associated with it?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Blaschko lines - Incontinentia pigmenti Explanation: The described linear rash following a distinct geometric pattern with parallel lines, often in a V-shaped distribution over the spine, is characteristic of Blaschko lines. Blaschko lines represent a pathway of normal epidermal cell migration during embryonic development. Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant disorder associated with Blaschko lines. It presents distinctive cutaneous findings, including linear vesicles, papules, and hyperpigmentation following the distribution of these lines. Other diseases associated with Blaschko disease are Epidermal naevi and Hypomelanosis of Ito. Options A and C: Langer lines refer to the natural orientation of collagen fibres in the skin, which influence wound healing and surgical incision planning. Gorlin syndrome, also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, is associated with multiple basal cell carcinomas, odontogenic keratocysts, and skeletal abnormalities but is not directly linked to Langer lines. Café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas characterize neurofibromatosis type 1 but are not specifically associated with Langer lines. Kraissl's lines (Option D) represent the relaxed skin tension lines of the breast and are pertinent in breast surgery planning. Linear morphea is a form of localized scleroderma characterized by linear patches of sclerosis, but it is not associated with Kraissl's lines.
